item.title: About
item.dc:creator: CTadmin
item.content:encoded:
This is an example page. It's different from a blog post because it will stay in one place and will show up in your site navigation (in most themes). Most people start with an About page that introduces them to potential site visitors. It might say something like this:
Hi there! I'm a bike messenger by day, aspiring actor by night, and this is my blog. I live in Los Angeles, have a great dog named Jack, and I like piña coladas. (And gettin' caught in the rain.)
...or something like this:
The XYZ Doohickey Company was founded in 1971, and has been providing quality doohickeys to the public ever since. Located in Gotham City, XYZ employs over 2,000 people and does all kinds of awesome things for the Gotham community.
As a new WordPress user, you should go to your dashboard to delete this page and create new pages for your content. Have fun!

item.title: Mixes
item.dc:creator: CTadmin

item.title: CT Q&A #003- The Levels Are Very High
item.dc:creator: CTadmin
item.content:encoded: Our third interview comes from none other then the very talented and incredible music seeker, Lvlsr Vryhi. The man puts in a ton of work not only in terms of putting together videos, but searching out some of the best music from around the world and Classical Trax couldn’t think of a better person to talk to for our third session of Q&A’s.Check him out photo credit to David Brimacombe interview by Juliette Boos of Handle The Sound http://handlethesound.tumblr.com/ J : Hi ! You’re alright ? L : Hullo - I’m fine, but had a fancy ready meal and then ruined it by eating a pot noodle so maybe a little annoyed with myself J: hahaha Could you tell me a bit more about « The Levels Are Very High » ? L : It’s predominantly a youtube channel (for rips, premieres and full videos that I make) and a mix series really - I’m interested in being able to give people (producers, DJs etc.) a platform (I guess in a similar way that Matt sees Classical Trax). It’s my way of getting involved but I see it more to do with ‘the scene’ than it is about me J : yeah that’s an alternative to own a label or something i guess it’s very nice though when about did you launched it? L: Haha thanks. I’ve always seen it as a bit cobbled together to be honest. According to youtube I started it in January of last year, but that was back when I was just ripping tracks. I don’t think I did anything for the first birthday hahah It’s definitely been long enough that I can’t really remember what free time is like - between this and university work I don’t really get a lot of it (my gf’s nodding her head in the corner right now haha) J : hahaha what are you studying at uni? yeah i know the feeling L : Art History I’m on the last stretch of my MA at the moment, finishing that in September (no summer for me) J : awww i’m sure you’ll be great do you also dj / produce besides all of this? L : I DJ in so much as I can mix and have drunkenly soundtracked a few parties. But I like doing guestmixes and it’s definitely something I want to focus on more when I’ve got the time. Right now though I’m definitely the guy looking in. I think my next few things are my Brunswick Sound mix and Matt is getting me to do half of a Radar show in September; that should be fun. RE: producing - I’ve got a maschine somewhere but any time I touch it I can’t even settle on a kick pattern. image J : ohhh i didnt really knew about you being a dj i have to admit that i’ve been sleeping on a lot of things recently L : I’m stuck with an unreadable DJ name - lvlsrvryhi doesn’t translate very well. Sleeping on things is a major worry of mine. Sometimes I’ll have a heavy weekend and be away from soundcloud and facebook for a couple of days and feel like the entire world has changed since I’ve been gone. J : hahaha me too Its seems like you’re digging a lot on the internet to find talented producers that are not known enough. Do you think you could be a stepping-stone for those people ? L : Actually, the other week WGWN - who was the first DJ to approach me wanting to do a mix - came down to Brighton for a night out and I think he pretty much said that (me being a stepping-stone etc.) himself. He was very far gone at the time though so maybe it was all fake haha. A lot of times, especially lately, I’ve asked people for mixes because, with there being so many aspects and points of reference for club and dance music culture now, the best way for me to shed some light on what’s going on is for the producers/DJs involved to filter it themselves. J : yeah that’s true what artists do you think need more hightlight then? L : Hahah. Guess I’ve got to pick out my favourites then. I’m not going to try and list off everyone I think deserves more hype because I’d just forget people or I’d mention someone and then tomorrow they’re picked up by one of the figureheads of a particular scene and I look like a bit of a fool. I’ve always been happy to use my channel/blog as if its literally me (with a logo standing in for my face I guess), so it’s approachable. I think that’s working, producers send me stuff all the time that I probably would’ve missed otherwise Really I think everyone should just listen to radio anyway so I’m gonna list off a bunch of shows I try and tune in to every week or month or whatever: 187, Mungo, SagePay, Riz La Teef, Akito, Crazylegs and Handsome Boys on Radar Trax Couture, Circadian Rhythms, Precious Metals, Slimzee and Roll Through on NTS Boxed and Celestial Trax on Rinse and anytime anyone from Staycore or NAAFI is on deck as well. J : yeah it’s hard to name them all haha does sometimes producers ask you to release like an EP on lvlsr? L : No one has come to me with anything more than a track so far I focus on trying to give back to anyone who gives to me, which is why I started making videos to go with tracks people wanted me to put up. Even if it’s a simpler thing I want to be involved and not benefiting from someone’s track without doing much myself If I ever was going to put up much more than one tune from someone I’d probably end up trying to do a video for each track and not go outside for a full week haha. J : haha yeah i see but do you think, in the future, you could become a label? and keeping making videos? or you prefer to keep it that way L : I’m not much of a future planner. I’ve got this .txt file that’s labelled “Schedule” in all caps and I don’t think I’ve opened it in about two weeks. I don’t think I’ll be turning into a label any time soon - I wouldn’t mind working on a compilation or something similar but I doubt it would be a regular thing. Me, Grime Disciple, Future Curse and Classical Trax may be developing a joint venture in the future. Though I’m also really disorganized so I might weigh everyone down haha. J : yeah you’re doing it the right way take your time everything doesnt have to end up as a label What’s your vision about the actual club scene ? L : Sometimes I’m pretty unsure what I mean when I talk about a 'scene’ to anyone. Most of my experience with it is massively virtual and definitely a product of being in a community like Classical Trax and knowing a bunch of London DJs. I think people can get a little too caught up in approaching club cultures as if they all habit the same space on the internet instead of properly taking in what’s around them, I’m 100% guilty of that myself. It’s great that collectives and aesthetics can exist without borders to some extent but it obviously leads to misrepresentation and co-option as easily as it does new relationships and a broadening of club culture as a whole. I’ve started tweeting at or messaging people when I like a tune of theirs because I think if you don’t engage with a producer you can basically consume their music and play it out yourself without their knowledge; then you just miss out on communicating with them and can’t reach more of an understanding behind what’s specific about what they’re doing. J : do you think people don’t talk enough to producers and all? L : Most people are a bit faceless on the internet so it can be difficult to see why you would try and interact with them. And yeah I wouldn’t expect every producer or DJ to respond to me just like I don’t get back to everyone who sends me a message, but I think the intention says a lot. Like, whether it’s just because I’m a bit drunk or whatever, I always try and say to a DJ if I think it was a good set if I see them out and it probably comes across really moist but they just got me to dance for an hour straight so I’ve already embarrassed myself plenty. J : awww yes do you go out a lot in brighton? how’s the music scene over there? L : A lot of new promoters have just come up, though most of them for House and Techno (Wave Function being an exception - they had a Wisdom Teeth night on last month) but there’s a massive lack of clubs for them - new venues are cropping up here and there but it’s definitely smaller than when I started uni like three and a half years ago. Really though the saviour of the scene are the Mute guys who’ve been around for a year or so now. They put on the nights I look forward to (besides one-offs) both in Brighton and in London and are kind of on their own thing bookings wise. One of the best things about living here though is being able to go up to London for a night out without much hassle - so I definitely get to experience music on a system and in a club regularly enough, money willing. J : Nice so much things i didnt.know Does the music scene in Brighton has influenced you in your tastes in matters of music ? L : I’d probably say no to be honest - I’ve always come at it looking for what I wanted to hear out rather than going on a whim. That’s probably a product of growing up and hearing and liking most of the UK-based club sounds before moving down here though. Becky (aka LVLSRVRY_GF): 'Stephen picks the nights out for our group of friends. Personally, I didn’t connect with club music that much before moving down to Brighton, but getting exposed to the stuff that he’s playing in his room (or my room) in a club environment has given it another dimension (especially communally). I’ve learnt what I do like and what I don’t like a lot more - not that that stops him from playing whatever he wants’ J : How do you proceed to make your videos ? L : I’ll listen to the tune a bunch of times and then just spend a day or so looking for sources that fit the mood of the tune (or just random stuff I think looks interesting). I’ve gotten in the habit of mapping out the patterns of each element in the tune and then messing with them to make them fit. A lot of times it can be a bit arduous and super time consuming, but I’m pretty happy with how most of the videos have come out. I used to bully windows movie maker into working for me, most of the early videos were with that and the quality fluctuated depending on how many times WMM crashed. Now I’m using premiere though and it’s more my computer freaking out than the program. I don’t think I’m really very good or experienced with it yet despite how many hours I’ve sunk in, but I’m pretty content with letting the tracks dictate the video rather than me. J : Yeah i think you are doing a very great job smile emoticon The interview is almost finished I just got one more thing It’s like an open question You say such interesting things so if there is any artist you like atm or city you wanna visit things you wanna experiment or type of music you think deserve more fame or anything really just tell me L : I’ve kind of thought of moving around and leaving the UK a fair amount and I would like to travel more, especially to visit the US since the last time I went I was more interested in the different flavours of cheetos and that cartoon network had 'rude stuff’ on after a certain time at night than club music (I was like 11). But I don’t think I’d ever really want to live anywhere else, I’m too entrenched here and I’d just get more annoyed with all the nights I was missing by not being near London (even though I miss loads now anyway). Most of the cities I’d want to go out to and experience things first hand are tied, for me at least, to particular labels/parties and what they’re doing there: Mexico City (for NAAFI), Lisbon (for Principe), Paris (for Sound Pellegrino) and Grenoble (for Narco Polo), Brooklyn (for Purple Tape Pedigree / AdHoc and DWMS), Kosovo (for Angry Youth), Milan (for Stream). There’s a bunch more obviously and I’m getting ahead of myself since I don’t have any money anyway haha. Really though, since I finish uni in September, I’m basically going to continue doing the same stuff I’ve been doing but step it up. And devote the time I was spending on university work on mixing so I can step onto my mate’s radio shows and ruin them all. As for an artist (if i had to pick one), and it might just be because he’s playing on Roll Through on NTS tonight, but ETEVLEH does not get enough attention. He sent me an EP a little while back that is a pretty original take on Grime, but no one has picked it up yet. He also seems to bring to it a lot of the same influences (musical and otherwise) that I’ve always been caught up in visually so I guess that’s another reason why I get a lot from his music. J : Okay thank you very much ! Check him out !!!!! http://lvlsrvryhigh.tumblr.com/ https://twitter.com/LVLSRVRYHI https://soundcloud.com/thelevelsareveryhigh https://www.facebook.com/TheLevelsAreVeryHigh https://www.youtube.com/user/thelevelsareveryhigh

The man puts in a ton of work not only in terms of putting together videos, but searching out some of the best music from around the world and Classical Trax couldn’t think of a better person to talk to for our third session of Q&A’s.Check him out

item.title: CT Q&A #004-Geng of PTP
item.dc:creator: CTadmin
item.content:encoded: You’re a purveyor of many things…DJing/producing/radio show hosting & designing (for Purple Tape Pedigree’s clothing range). When was it that you realised you had an interest in all these areas? I caught the music bug real young! By first grade, I was sneaking rap music videos after school (shout out Video Music Box) and had my walkman radio tuned to KISS FM on Saturday nights with the volume super low so my pops wouldn’t hear whatever Mr. Magic was playing. When I was 13-14 years old, I knew I had to get into it and I always thought the DJ was the cool guy. I fucked around with making pause tapes and writing little bullshit raps in class…but it wasn’t until I hit freshman year of high school - I saved up enough for turntables and got some belt-driven Gemini’s. I taught myself how to mix and scratch on those dainty things - spent DAYS in my room working on mixes. The routine then was, every Friday, myself and a few friends worked on a mixtape for that week, wrote/recorded freestyle rap intros, slept, then woke up and went shopping for new releases/bootlegs/promos/white labels, then came back and repeated until it was Monday, again. I went through phases with it. One point I was a full-on DJ. Then I wanted to rap which led me to get my first “sampler” (Roland JS-30…jeez) and figure out how to make beats. Then I saved enough and bought 1200’s and got pretty decent at being a technical DJ. I quit halfway through college, wanting to just rap and produce. I ended up doing a few shows as a rapper, actually, my first and only solo show was in the basement of CBGB’s at this party my guys Bricks Avalon and HCR (now Ron Morelli, of L.I.E.S.) used to throw as VF Productions. Still have that footage somewhere. In 2004, I ended up getting some beats over to the Diplomats and actually got two tracks placed. That was an experience - kind of left me not wanting to ever have to rely on someone else (i.e. a manager), so since then, I’ve toyed with two different “indie/D.I.Y.” imprints: Sonic Drunk (2005-2008) and Purple Tape Pedigree (2009-forever). The clothes came about because I’ve always wanted to customize my gear and I was once in a hardcore band (I guess) - a stint during which yielded a fairly larger amount of merch than finished music. That’s what got me into dealing with screen-printed graphic tees as a medium. Growing up, who/what were your biggest inspirations when it came to envisaging a career in music and fashion? Biggest inspirations: RZA, Tricky, Tom Waits, Rodney Mullen, Peter Gabriel, army suits, Blade Runner, Bjork, Roc Raida, Stretch & Bobbito, Bill Murray, being a teen in 90’s New York City. Talk me through how you and Note (your right-hand in PTP & co-host of the now-defunct Fresh Out the Box) came to meet? Haaaa! Real shit, we first connected on an Internet forum called Superfuture, back in 2007/2008. There was a small group of heads who would exchange posts about rap, hardcore punk/metal, old cyberpunk computer games, anime, etc. - rather than “What Are You Wearing Today?” You could also always sniff out another New Yorker on the message boards, so we had a few friendly exchanges. One day he ran up on me in Soho like, “Yo! What’s good man?” I guess he recognized me from my Myspace profile I had linked a few times? Shit was pretty automatic since then and after about a year of me running the old Purple Tape Pedigree blog, I felt like I could use another hand. I trusted him fully and he was down to work. Note’s a very rare breed of friend to find: 1000% loyalty and wit. …This is a bit of a random question but what was it that inspired the name for PTP? “Purple Tape” is a reference to the Raekwon album, Only Built 4 Cuban Linx. People started calling it the “purple tape” because it came out as a purple cassette - really rare that a tape would be a colour other than clear or black back then. That’s a hustler’s move to separate his/her product from the rest. To this day, the purple tape is one of our favorite albums of all-time. PTP basically means “striving for perfection.” You established PTP in 2009 and when you look back on your collective’s existence up to now, what are the moments that stand out in your mind as ones you’re really proud of? The numerous “family-style” meals we’ve had and how the table has grown over the years, hahaha. The really solid handshakes and numerous late nights we’ve shared. You’re a native New Yorker and chose to stay in your hometown for your career…what is it about the city that you really like? Was there ever a point when you considered relocating somewhere else to pursue your interests? I feel like my career is still “just beginning,” you know? In the way that I haven’t yet felt that “grand statement making moment” occur. As much as New York has changed, for better or for worse, it’s still a rather electric place. I’m kind of addicted to the chaotic pacing of it all. Lately, I’ve been trying to clock the way my mind works, in terms of how I manage to remind myself of 3rd-tier tasks for the day, those which I forgot to jot down earlier. There’s a lot to experience and so much diversity, still. Yes, I’ve definitely considered moving elsewhere to change things up - perhaps to make it all feel super new and lower the risk of a heart attack (or just so I can have that much of an edge up on everyone else who are moving at 1/10th the speed). Sometimes, it’s like, “fuck it, I'ma move to Portland, Maine, and create in some little bubble.” But I think a move for me would be best as a giant leap to a new, bustling country and currency: somewhere in Asia. For someone who’s never visited New York (or even the States for that matter), what nights/shops/restaurants/bars etc, would you recommend if you were to be my ‘city guide’ as it were? I AM THE CITY GUIDE. ASK ABOUT ME. But really, like I kinda said, there’s a lot I’m still finding as new, experience-wise, in this city. I’d definitely say the museums (American Museum of Natural History, especially), downtown (Soho and East Village) for shopping and food, Chinatown Fair arcade and Mei Li Wah’s baked roast pork buns and mad food in Chinatown, Joe’s for a certified plain slice of NYC pizza, Sunny & Annie’s for the best sandwiches you can get 24 hours a day, H&H for the best “everything bagel” you can get 24 hours a day, 2nd Ave Deli for pastrami/corned beef/brisket on rye, uptown 119th or Dyckman for the haze/piff, Astoria (Queens) for B.Z. Grill and more food, Brooklyn to hit Palisades for a proper D.I.Y. venue that is up for anything. As far as nights, it ranges. So much goes on, every week…but also venues change for the various parties so it’s hard to really subscribe to many of them. That’s why I choose to stay at Palisades for the DWMS series PTP puts on - if it ain’t broke… But massive love to Mixpak, Reconstrvct, and AdHoc: some of the most consistent night-makers, for many years now. I hear you’re coming over to London in November…what have you got planned? Yeaaaa…gonna be the first time across the Atlantic! I’ll be playing a bunch of things it looks like: nights as well as radio. Shouts to everyone trying to lock it down, but can’t announce anything quite yet - it’s gonna be a full 2-weeks. Wanna definitely say “hi” to my HER Records fam, Trax Couture, Local Action, Coyote, Liminal Sounds, Crazylegs, Gang Fatale, Dark0, Wen, Tropical Waste, Bala Club, and plenty more. Also, looking to get out to Dublin and play a night with Glacial Sound and co. Looking to hang with as many of the British crew as possible. There’s gonna be 4-6 of us PTP heads out there. Gonna eat lots of curry and recreate Animal House via someone’s Air BNB Finally…what have you and Note got planned for PTP for the remainder of the year and into 2016? Are there any other areas you guys would like to branch out into? I’ve got a pretty tight/hefty release schedule planned for September through the first quarter of 2016. The plan this year was to fully establish PTP as a record label (beyond other things). It’s looking VERY clear that this is about to happen in a really lovely way. Putting out some split 12"s with talent from HER Rex, Gang Fatale, NAAFI, Keysound, and some surprises. Also, releasing Joey Labeija’s Shattered Dreams album (limited release on vinyl), an EP by DJ New Jersey Drone, and some other things I’ll keep on the low for a bit more. Expect a video or two, as well! DWMS10 is October 10th - the last one of the year. I’ll also be playing a few shows as well as finishing up some more mixes, continuing our monthly PTP x Radar Radio show, and working on more of my own music. Note will be doing visuals for DWMS10 (as has been the case since the beginning), and I know he is working on some other graphical/motion-active things. Shit, he’s probably gonna take some of that to London and put on a show for ya’ll. Note’s the guy who will pop up with another crazy shirt or two tomorrow - always got something in the works. Everyone in the crew is a workhorse on his/her own. They inspire and push me to do more, all the time. I really love them. out to Geng and the entire PTP squad https://soundcloud.com/purpletapepedigree http://www.twitter.com/purpicide
item.excerpt:encoded: Our fourth interview in our Q&A series comes from one of my favorite curators, deejays and just a all around honest and great person, Geng. Check out the amazing interview.
